description.narrative:
Helvetas, an international NGO, has developed a proposal covering the establishment of a regional inclusive economic development programme, where the main part of the budget (75%) is dedicated to regional level work Eastern Europe and a country window for Armenia. The remaining part is dedicated to Western Balkans including a small North Macedonia window. The intervention, amounting to 35 million SEK, is an inception- and pilot phase in preparation of two larger long term programmes in Eastern Europe and Western Balkans which are expected to start during spring 2022.
The intervention framework applies an inclusive market systems development approach where the inception phase consists of a set of deliverables relating to research, analysis, institution building and piloting of interventions for possible scale-up within a longer term programme. A number of local partners will be engaged in the implementation and Helvetas has the right to forward funds accordingly. The expected results are process targets relating to programme design and institutionalization, combined with some early outcome effects on employment and incomes (4,000 people) and improved employability (skills improvements for around 8,000 people).

Helvetas, en internationell enskild organisation, har utvecklat ett förslag på etablering av en regional sysselsättningsinsats, varav merparten avser landspecifikt arbete i Armenien, och regionalt arbete i Östeuropa (75%). Återstoden allokeras till arbete på Västra Balkan, inklusive ett litet landfönster för Nordmakedonien.
Insatsen uppgår till 35 miljoner SEK och omfattar 22 månaders inceptions- och pilotarbete för två större regionala program i Östeuropa och på Västra Balkan, med förväntad start under våren 2022.
Insatsen tillämpar en inkluderande marknadssystemansats och innevarande fas består av komponenter som forskning, analys, institutionsuppbyggnad och testning av en rad insatshypoteser för uppskalning i ett långsiktigt program. Ett antal internationella och lokala organisationer förväntas bidra till genomförandet, och Helvetas har rätt att vidareförmedla medel för detta ändamål. De förväntade resultaten är huvudsakligen processmål samt vissa effekter på sysselsättning och inkomstskapande (4 000 personer) och förbättrad anställningsbarhet (förbättrade yrkesrelaterade färdigheter för 8 000 personer).

The intervention is a research and piloting phase of a larger and longer term expected programme. As such, the majority of objectives relate to deliverables in research, piloting, institutionalization and long term design work as outlines in the Inception Plan section of the Proposal (Annex 7.2). In addition to the output level deliverables referenced above, the pilot interventions envisioned for this phase is expected to yield some early development outcomes in themselves (Annex 7.1). The ultimate objectives of the longer term programme envisioned are improved incomes and employment opportunities for economically disadvantaged people. Women and youth are pre-defined as belonging to this group. A hypothetical assessment presented in the results framework attached to the Proposal, is that around 12,000 people's lives are likely to be affected by changes catalyzed by the project. The effect is a mix of improved incomes or employment opportunities per se, and partial gains such as improved skills aligned with real demands from the business sector.

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.

1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

1.a - Ensure significant mobilization of resources from a variety of sources, including through enhanced development cooperation, in order to provide adequate and predictable means for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, to implement programmes and policies to end poverty in all its dimensions.

1.a - Säkra en betydande resursmobilisering från en mängd olika källor, inklusive genom ökat utvecklingssamarbete, i syfte att ge utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna, tillräckliga och förutsebara medel för att genomföra program och politik för att avskaffa all form av fattigdom.

1.b - Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender-sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.

1.b - Upprätta sunda policyramverk på nationell, regional och internationell nivå på grundval av utvecklingsstrategier som stödjer de fattiga och tar hänsyn till jämställdhetsaspekter, för att stödja ökade investeringar i åtgärder för att avskaffa fattigdom.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.

8.4 - Fram till 2030 successivt förbättra den globala resurseffektiviteten i konsumtionen och produktionen samt sträva efter att bryta sambandet mellan ekonomisk tillväxt och miljöförstöring, i enlighet med det tioåriga ramverket för hållbar konsumtion och produktion, med de utvecklade länderna i täten.

8.4 - Improve progressively, through 2030, global resource efficiency in consumption and production and endeavour to decouple economic growth from environmental degradation, in accordance with the 10-Year Framework of Programmes on Sustainable Consumption and Production, with developed countries taking the lead.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.
8.6 - By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
8.6 - Till 2020 väsentligt minska den andel ungdomar som varken arbetar eller studerar.

description.narrative: The progress of the first twelve months of work has manifested itself on process level only. Development results are expected to start materializing from mid 2021. Process level achievements include the following: Overall performance. Reconomy’s management team have been extraordinarily committed, knowledgeable and responsive. They have successfully established a remarkably complex programme in an extremely difficult, variable and geographically diverse environment, where challenges have also been heavily exacerbated by Covid-19 and conflict dynamics. A programme organization has been put in place and fully staffed with a well-balanced team of committed and professional people. Half a dozen of pilot interventions have been designed and kicked off in an iterative process anchored in pre-existing and complementary market systems assessments (MSA). Partnerships with local implementers have been agreed for all the (five) pilot projects approved so far. Pilot partners express a high degree of satisfaction with the programme approach as well as value-additions and relationships with Helvetas and Reconomy staff. Helvetas has also supported Sida with a large number of high quality inputs and “second opinions” of various institutions and initiatives in the region. This has allowed Sida to perform even better in multi-stakeholder consultations and external programme design. They have also held a large number of capacity building events on the topic of inclusive systemic programming for partners and Sida colleagues in the regions. (See progress reports and related statements for more information.) Contents-wise, the pilot projects so far initiated appear to over-emphasize skills interventions/development. This may be natural during a short-term inception programme, but it is expected to evolve more tangibly towards other employment-related bottlenecks in the design report conclusions and longer-term programme outlooks to be presented during 2021. Challenges encountered were overall expected since the MSD approach with inclusive systemic programming hasn’t been comprehensively tested at regional level before. Additionally, Helvetas have more experiences and networks on the Western Balkans than in Eastern Europe where Reconomy (including the Armenia window) has 2/3 of their operations. The wide geographical coverage of Reconomy also solicited establishment of new institutional modes of operation for Helvetas, creating a somewhat unpredictable period of institutionalization over the past year. Covid-19 and outbreak of war in Armenia delayed the initial round of market systems assessments, when researchers couldn’t operate as usual given mobility restrictions in and between countries. The MSA itself has until today not provided a foundational level of information which would allow for comfortable pilot project approvals. While the backbones of target group and sector analytics have come into place, elements perceived to fall short of aspirations according to the ToR include the stakeholder mapping and engagement strategy, as well as a data baseline for results measurement. Additionally, the MSA doesn’t give a coherent and convincing narrative to intervention in the advocacy system (including the anti-corruption workstream), in general or in the targeted pilot countries. Green growth opportunities and access to finance are poorly covered areas. Several perspectives in the ToR are still missing such as political economy, trade dynamics, EU-integration, broader relations with the Swedish resource base. Sida's perspectives can be generally strengthened in the MSA, and bigger proportion of attention given to Armenia and MNK. While a detailed stakeholder mapping and partnership selection will allegedly be submitted with pilot concept notes for no objection, these can’t be expected to provide the full picture. The same goes for the mapping Sida’s employment related programmes in the region. The gradual development of the MSA will have to be monitored continuously, so that the picture is sufficiently clear by the time Sida need to decide on directions for longer term employment programming. Meanwhile, Reconomy’s intended pilot interventions were in themselves dependent on initial market assessments caused delays when they couldn’t intervene at the pace and scale envisioned under budget cluster 3. Budget utilization for this cluster was only 38% for H2 2020 and the total utilization came out at 57%. We have also noted challenges less clearly linked to Covid-19 and conflict dynamics: The programme management has been over-worked and the ProDoc strategy of dynamically engaging auxiliary expertise from within Helvetas and partner organizations fell flat to almost zero utilization of the related budget line during 2020. Some improvements and re-balancing of workload has been noted during the second quarter of 2021. Expectations management. Communications in materials submitted to Sida wasn’t perceived as clear enough regarding the distinct nature of the inception phase programme including its pilot approaches. Recalling that Sida can’t commit to any engagement beyond ongoing (signed) agreements, reputation risk need to be better managed by delineating pilot projects and establishing clear exit strategies and communication from the start. Helvetas has committed to improving communication in this regard, and improvements have indeed been noted during Q2 2021. Risk management. Risk analysis and mitigation need to be deepened and closely monitored during 2021, not least relating to utilization rates and the effects that further delays will have on the room for implementing actual pilots. Risk assessments for pilots show remarkably low levels of risk, in particular compared to the significant delays in implementation already encountered. There seem to be reason to deepen the approach to risk analysis and mitigation strategies, including at the “internal” level of institutional and partnership risks. Upholding staff positions beyond agreed activity period negatively impact space for pilot related forwarding. Helvetas have been requested to update the risk management matrix from the ProDoc with internal risks (i.e. institutional, organizational, partnerships, anti-corruption) in the proposal for cost extension of Reconomy. Compliance. It required a large number of iterations over two months in order for the financial report to be clear and fulfil Sida’s agreement conditions. Compliance with agreement conditions have been subject for numerous exchanges with Helvetas over the past year. The exchanges are not perceived to be of serious nature, but go beyond what can be considered 'minor differences of interpretation' between the parties. Related attention will have to stay in the spotlight, and compliance functions will need further strengthening. As part of this process, Sida has recommended Helvetas to strengthen their overall legal/compliance support function. Although there are of legal advisers accessible for particular tasks, compliance officers and internal auditing processes don’t seem to make a holistic engagement. Support functions don't substitute for management’s need to know and profoundly understand the partnership agreement, but can support managers to get things right in a timely manner. It would also facilitate Sida’s approvals. While pilot concept notes have been gradually improved in terms of clarity of objectives and division of responsibilities, there still seems to be a high risk that not all relevant parties have the same picture of ongoing work as the one submitted to Sida. The 'knowledge hubs' described in the ProDoc as an integral part of the Reconomy approach have been delayed. Their implementation relate to above points on MSA and fact finding for pilot approvals, coordination with ongoing developments and programmes in the regions, refinements of pilot approaches and expectations management. Delays negatively affect the clarity and strategic positioning of the programme, internally as well as with external stakeholders. Helvetas has committed to improvement in this area. Communication and data/information management has also been negatively affected by the delay in establishment of a document portal or website. The website was supposed to cater strategic information to external audiences, but also (using restricted access areas) facilitate information sharing between Helvetas, Sida and implementing partners. The service provider for the website has not delivered as expected. The development of a private sector engagement (PSE) guideline for Sida’s approval took Helvetas until end of January 2021, and the approval process took another month due to needs for alignment with Sida’s legal standards. In the end the policy turned out very restrictive, and opportunities for additional engagement formats and instruments will have to be researched sequentially. There is a perceived and somewhat concerning picture of interpretations around the PSE guideline concept of “competitive selection” and understanding of market distortions. A special session on competitive selection and market distortions was held in the 2-monthly review meeting with Helvetas management, staff, partners and advisers in May 2021. DCED guidelines on this topic should be further anchored within Helvetas and partners, and regular exchanged with Sida should be held for alignment with legal requirements and mandates. The governance structure has matured during the first year of operations, but can be further refined. It will be important to keep the Programme Advisory Board (PAB) nimble (maximum 8-10 people as originally envisioned) and align members’ understanding of purpose. PAB role in refining pilot concepts also need to be better effectuated in line with the partnership Agreement (Article 13.1). Institutional turf issues between facilitating and co-facilitating NGO's can always emerge in complex development setups, balancing needs of various in-depth specialist competencies on one hand, and a need for overall market systems expertise and orientation at the other.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
